Well, see, my wife’s been getting on me a lot lately about improving my health habits. I don’t really see what the big problem is, though. I mean, I’ve been working really hard. Sometimes I can’t make it home for dinner, so I end up eating out at places like Applebee’s. But she seems to think it’s a bigger deal than it is.
It sounds like your wife is coming from a place of care, but you’re feeling like her concerns might not fully align with how you see things right now. Is that right?
Yeah, exactly. I mean, I feel fine. I don’t see why she’s so worried.

Got it. So, from your perspective, you’re feeling okay, and her concerns feel a bit over the top. Can you tell me more about how you’re feeling physically? Like, how’s your energy level or how you’re keeping up with your work?

Oh, I feel good. My job is pretty physically demanding—I’m out in the hot sun most of the day, doing a lot of manual labor. I’m always sweating, so I figure I’m burning off anything unhealthy I might eat.

That makes sense. It sounds like your job keeps you active, and you feel like that balances things out. Have you noticed any changes in how your body feels, though? Like, maybe your weight or how your clothes fit?
Well, I’ve put on a little weight, but it’s nothing crazy. I don’t feel bloated or anything like that.
Okay. And have you had a chance to check in with a doctor recently, just to see how things are going health-wise?
Yeah, I had a physical last year. Everything came back normal, so I haven’t really thought much about it since then.

That’s good to hear. So, overall, you’re feeling pretty good, and the doctor didn’t raise any concerns. But it sounds like your wife’s worries are still on your mind. How do you feel about her bringing this up so often?

I mean, I know she’s coming from a good place. She loves me and wants me to be healthy and live a long life. But sometimes, after a long day at work, going out to eat feels like a little reward, you know? It helps me unwind.

Absolutely. It sounds like those meals out are more than just food—they’re a way to take care of yourself emotionally after a tough day. At the same time, it seems like you’re open to understanding why your wife might be concerned. Would it be okay if we explored that a bit? Maybe talk about how small changes could fit into your routine without taking away those moments that help you feel good?
Yeah, I’m open to that. I mean, I do want to make sure I’m healthy for her and for myself.

That’s a great mindset. Let’s start with some small, manageable steps. For example, have you ever thought about how small tweaks to your meals—whether at home or eating out—could make a difference over time? It doesn’t have to be all or nothing.
Yeah, I guess I could try that. I don’t want to give up eating out entirely, but maybe I could make better choices when I do.
That’s a really practical approach. Small changes can add up, and they don’t have to take away from the enjoyment you get from those meals. How does that sound to you?
It sounds good. I’m willing to give it a try.
That’s great to hear. Let’s take it one step at a time and see how it goes. And remember, I’m here to support you through this process.
Hi, Emily. It’s good to see you again. How have you been?
Hi. Yeah, I’ve been okay. It’s been a while, huh?
It has. I noticed something new about you today—your lip piercing. It looks great! How long have you had it?
Thanks! I got it about a month ago.
A month ago? What inspired you to get it?
I don’t know, really. I just wanted to try something different. I was feeling kind of stuck, and I thought it might be fun to stand out a little.
That makes sense. Sometimes a change can feel refreshing. How has it been for you so far?
It’s been good. I like how it looks, and it’s been a fun little change.
That’s great to hear. You know, as your dentist, I do have some concerns about how oral piercings can affect teeth and gums. Have you heard much about that?
Not really. I mean, I guess it could push on my gums or teeth, but I’m not sure how much of an issue it would actually be. My teeth are pretty strong, so I haven’t worried too much.

That’s true—you do have strong, healthy teeth, which is something we’ve always worked to maintain. But I’ve seen some patients with oral piercings develop gum erosion or even chipped teeth from the jewelry. What are your thoughts on that?

Oh, I didn’t realize it could chip teeth. I definitely don’t want to mess up my teeth. I know you’ve mentioned my gums are already a bit low, and I’m supposed to be flossing more… which, uh, I’m still working on.

[chuckles] Yes, flossing is always a work in progress for most of us. But it’s good you’re aware of your gum health. If you noticed any changes, like gum recession or tooth damage, how would you feel about the piercing then?
I guess if I saw it was causing problems, I’d probably take it out. I mean, I like it, but my teeth are more important. I just got it, though, so I haven’t noticed anything yet.
That’s fair. It’s still pretty new, and you’re paying attention to how it feels. What would help you stay aware of any potential issues as time goes on?
I guess I’d just keep an eye on it. If I noticed my gums looking different or my teeth feeling weird, I’d probably rethink it. But for now, it’s just kind of a fun thing.

That sounds like a balanced approach. You’re enjoying it while also being mindful of your health. You mentioned earlier that your teeth are more important—that’s a really thoughtful perspective. How do you feel about balancing self-expression, like the piercing, with taking care of your teeth?
I mean, I want both, but if I had to choose, I’d pick my teeth. They’re kind of permanent, you know? The piercing might not last forever, but I’m hoping my teeth will.

You said that so well, Emily. The piercing is temporary, but your teeth are for life. It’s clear you’ve thought this through. Thanks for sharing your perspective with me. Before we move on to the exam, let’s talk about flossing—how’s that going for you lately?
[laughs] Oh, flossing… yeah, I’m still trying to get better at that. I know I need to do it more.
It’s a process, and I’m here to help. Let’s brainstorm some ways to make it easier for you. What’s been the biggest challenge with flossing regularly?
I think I just forget to do it. I’m not in the habit yet.
That’s a common hurdle. What if we tried tying it to something you already do every day, like brushing your teeth? Could that help you remember?
Yeah, that might work. I’ll give it a try.
Great! Small steps can make a big difference. Let’s check in on that next time. Ready for your exam?
Sure, let’s do it.
Hi, Sal. Thanks for coming in today. I know it’s not always easy to make time for these appointments, so I really appreciate you being here.
Yeah, no problem. I mean, it’s a bit of a hassle, but I’m here.
I saw that your doctor referred you, and I’m curious—what’s your understanding of why she thought it might be helpful for us to talk?
I don’t know, honestly. She’s been on me about making more changes—quit smoking, cut back on drinking, even getting rid of my dog. It’s like, what else does she want from me?
It sounds like there’s a lot on your plate right now. Not just the asthma, but other things too.
Yeah, it’s a lot. My wife’s still on maternity leave, so she’s not getting paid, and I’m the only one working right now. Plus, all these changes I’m supposed to make—it’s just… a lot.
It sounds overwhelming, like you’re juggling so much at once.
Yeah, it really is. It’s like everything’s piling up, and I don’t even know where to start.

I hear that. It’s tough when it feels like everything’s coming at you all at once. We’ve got about 20 minutes today, and I wonder if it would be helpful to take a step back and look at everything that’s going on. Maybe we can figure out what feels most important to focus on right now. How does that sound?
Yeah, I guess that makes sense. It’s all over the place, but we’ve got to start somewhere, right?

Exactly. Sometimes it helps to just lay everything out and see what’s most pressing. I’ve got a kind of worksheet here—it’s just a way to list out the things that are on your mind or that others are suggesting you work on. And just to be clear, Sal, listing them doesn’t mean you have to do anything about them right now. This is about you deciding what feels most important to you.
Okay, that sounds good. As long as it’s not like, “You have to fix all this right now.”
Not at all. You’re in the driver’s seat here. So, what’s one thing that comes to mind?
Well, my asthma’s been acting up a lot lately.
Okay, so asthma is one. What else?
Um, the whole thing about my dog, Oscar. The doctor says he’s making my asthma worse and that I should get rid of him.
That’s a big one. It sounds like that’s really hitting hard for you.
Yeah, it’s… it’s a lot. I’ve had Oscar longer than I’ve known my wife. He’s like my best friend. I can’t just get rid of him like that.
It’s not just a pet—it’s a relationship. That’s a huge thing to be asked to give up.
Exactly. It’s really stressing me out.
I can imagine. What else is on your mind?
Well, I’ve been trying to cut down on smoking, but it’s hard. And finances are a mess right now—my wife’s not working, and I’m taking time off for all these appointments, which isn’t helping.
So smoking, finances, and the time these appointments take—those are all connected, it sounds like.
Yeah, and there’s the drinking too. I’m supposed to cut back on that as well.
Wow, Sal, that’s a lot to manage. It’s no wonder you’re feeling overwhelmed. If you had to pick one or two things to focus on today, what would feel most important to you?
I think the dog situation is really bothering me. And my asthma—it’s been out of control lately.
Okay, so Oscar and your asthma. Those seem pretty connected, don’t they?
Yeah, they are. I just don’t know what to do about it.

It’s a tough spot to be in. How about we spend some time exploring that? Maybe we can look at what’s most important to you about Oscar and how that fits with managing your asthma. Does that sound okay?
Yeah, that sounds good.
Great. Let’s start there.

column5: therapist So, I understand you sprained your ankle yesterday. Can you tell me a little more about how that happened?

client Ugh, it’s so embarrassing. I was at a 90s-themed pub crawl last night, and, well, you know how those go—lots of drinks, lots of fun. I was trying to catch up with my friends who were ahead of me, and I thought it’d be a great idea to jump off the bus stairs… in stilettos. Yeah, not my brightest moment. I landed wrong and twisted my ankle. It was so awkward.
therapist Ouch. That sounds like quite the night! How are you feeling about it now?
client Honestly? A little frustrated with myself. I mean, it was fun until that moment, but now I’m stuck with this ankle and a killer hangover.
therapist It sounds like you’re reflecting on the consequences of last night. I’m curious—how does this fit into your usual routine? Do nights like this happen often?
client I mean, not every night, but weekends are usually when I let loose. I’m a university student, so it’s pretty normal to go out with friends and have a few drinks.
therapist Got it. So, weekends are your time to unwind and socialize. When you say “a few drinks,” what does that look like for you?
client Well, if we’re going out, it’s more than a few. I’d say… seven or eight drinks, maybe? And sometimes I’ll have a beer or two during the week if I’ve had a long day studying.
therapist I see. So, it sounds like alcohol plays a role in both your social life and your downtime. How do you feel about that balance right now?
client I don’t know. I guess I haven’t really thought about it. It just feels normal, you know? Everyone around me is doing the same thing.

therapist That makes sense. It can be hard to step back and evaluate something when it feels like the norm. I’m wondering—have you ever thought about how your drinking might be affecting you, physically or otherwise?
client I mean, I definitely feel it today. My ankle hurts, I’m exhausted, and I know I’m not as productive when I’m hungover. So, yeah, there’s that.
therapist It sounds like you’re noticing some downsides. Do you think there could be benefits to cutting back a little, even just to see how it feels?
client Maybe. I do like the idea of feeling better and getting more done. But I don’t know—it’s such a big part of my social life.

therapist That’s a really valid point. Balancing social connections with personal well-being can be tricky. What if we took a moment to look at some guidelines for low-risk drinking? It might help give you a clearer picture of what’s considered safe.
client Sure, I guess that could be interesting.
therapist Great. For women, the low-risk guideline is about 10 drinks per week, with no more than 2 drinks a day. How does that compare to what you’re currently drinking?
client Oh, wow. I’m definitely over that. Especially during midterms—I feel like I drink more to deal with the stress.
therapist It sounds like stress plays a big role in your drinking habits. Do you think there are other ways you could manage that stress, or is alcohol the go-to for now?
client I mean, I know there are other ways, but drinking is just… easier, I guess.

therapist That’s understandable. It’s hard to change habits, especially when they feel like a quick fix. But it sounds like you’re already noticing some benefits to cutting back—like feeling more productive and avoiding hangovers.
client Yeah, that’s true. I do like the idea of feeling better overall.

therapist That’s a great insight. It sounds like you’re open to exploring this further. Would you be interested in coming back to talk more about this when you’re feeling a bit better? Maybe we could brainstorm some strategies to help you balance socializing and well-being.
client Yeah, I think that could be helpful. Maybe not right now, though—I’m still recovering from last night.
therapist Of course. How about we schedule something for later this week or early next week? That way, you’ll have some time to reflect and we can dive deeper when you’re ready.
client That works for me. Just not on a Saturday morning—I’ll probably be recovering again. [laughs]
therapist [chuckles] Fair enough. Let’s find a time that works for you. Thanks for being so open today—it’s not easy to reflect on these things, and I really appreciate your honesty.
client Thanks. I think it’s good to talk about it, even if it’s a little uncomfortable.
therapist Absolutely. I’ll see you soon, and take care of that ankle in the meantime.

column6: utterance_text
So, Bob, what brings you in today? What’s on your mind, and how can I help?

Honestly, I’m only here because my wife thinks I have a problem with smoking. I’ve been smoking most of my life, and it’s never been an issue—until six months ago. She got into this health kick, and now she’s on this mission to get me to quit. I’m here to make her happy, but honestly, I don’t see the big deal.
It sounds like this isn’t something you’d choose to do on your own. You’re here more for her than for yourself.

Exactly. I mean, I’m supposed to be at work right now. This is costing me time and money, and I’m only here because she’s been nagging me nonstop for months. She quit smoking, and now she expects me to do the same.
That must feel frustrating—like you’re being pushed into something you’re not ready for. What’s it been like for you, having her and maybe others pressuring you to quit?

It’s been awful. She’s cut out all these articles about smoking and makes me read them over breakfast. We used to smoke together, and now I have to go outside in the cold while she acts like she’s better than me. And now she’s got the kids on her side too—it’s like they’re all ganging up on me.
So, it’s not just about the smoking anymore—it’s about feeling isolated, like everyone’s turned against you. That must be really tough.
Yeah, it is. I mean, I love my family, and I don’t want to lose them over this. But it feels like they’re asking me to change everything overnight, and I don’t know if I can do that.
It sounds like your family means a lot to you, and you’re worried this could drive a wedge between you. At the same time, quitting smoking feels like a huge, overwhelming task. Is that right?
Yeah, that’s it exactly. I’ve thought about quitting before, but it’s not easy. My dad’s 85, and he still smokes. I don’t know if I can just stop like my wife did.

It sounds like you’re caught between two things: wanting to keep your family happy and feeling like quitting smoking is this massive, almost impossible challenge. What if there were a way to approach this that didn’t feel so all-or-nothing?
What do you mean?

Well, quitting smoking doesn’t have to happen overnight. It’s a process, and there are ways to make it more manageable—like cutting back gradually or using tools to help you along the way. How does that sound to you?
That actually sounds better. I mean, I’ve been feeling like it’s either keep smoking and lose my family or quit completely and feel miserable. But if there’s a middle ground, I’d be willing to try.

That’s a great perspective. It’s about finding what works for you, at your own pace. Would it help if your wife understood that too? Maybe she could join us for a session so we can all be on the same page.
Yeah, that might help. She’s convinced I need to quit cold turkey, but if she heard from you that it’s okay to take it step by step, it might take some of the pressure off.
Absolutely. If you’d like to bring her along, we can work together to create a plan that feels doable for you and reassures her that you’re taking steps toward change.
Okay, I’ll talk to her about it. Her schedule’s pretty unpredictable, but I’ll call you tomorrow to set something up.
That sounds like a good plan. I appreciate you being open to this, Bob. It’s not easy to take these steps, especially when you’re feeling pressured.
Thanks. I guess I just needed to hear that there’s another way to do this.
You’re welcome. I’m here to support you, and we’ll take it one step at a time. Thanks for coming in today.
Thanks. I’ll be in touch.
Hi there! How are you doing today?
I’m okay, I guess. Just a bit overwhelmed.
I can understand that. It sounds like you’ve got a lot on your mind. What’s been going on?
Well, I just got diagnosed with diabetes. My doctor said my blood sugar is really high, and I need to make a lot of changes.
That’s a big piece of news to take in. How are you feeling about the diagnosis?
Honestly, I’m scared. My doctor was really serious about it—she mentioned things like losing my eyesight or even my feet if I don’t manage it. It’s a lot to process.
That sounds really overwhelming. It’s not easy to hear something like that, especially when it feels like there’s so much at stake. What stood out to you the most from what your doctor said?

I think just how serious it is. I didn’t realize how much damage it could do if I don’t take care of myself. But it feels like there’s so much to do—medication, diet, exercise… I don’t even know where to start.

It’s completely normal to feel that way. It sounds like you’re aware of the importance of managing this, but it also feels like a huge mountain to climb. What do you think would be the smallest step you could take to start moving in the right direction?
I guess… maybe looking at my diet? I know I don’t eat the best, and that’s something I could try to change. But it’s hard—I’m so used to eating the way I do.
That’s a great starting point. Changing habits can be challenging, especially when they’ve been part of your life for a long time. What do you think might help you make those changes?
I’m not sure. Maybe finding some healthier recipes or something? I don’t know if I can do it all at once, though.
That’s a really practical idea. Taking it one step at a time can make it feel less overwhelming. What’s one small change you could make this week to your diet that feels manageable?
Maybe cutting back on soda? I drink a lot of it, and I know it’s not good for me.
That’s a great first step. Small changes like that can add up over time. How do you think cutting back on soda might help you feel more in control of your health?
I think it would make me feel like I’m doing something, you know? Like I’m not just sitting here waiting for things to get worse.
That’s a really powerful insight. Taking action, even in small ways, can help you feel more empowered. How do you think you’ll feel if you’re able to make that change this week?
I think I’d feel proud of myself. Like I’m finally taking steps to take care of myself.

That’s wonderful. It sounds like you’re ready to start making some changes, and that’s a big deal. Let’s work together to figure out how to support you in this process. What else do you think might help you stay on track?
Maybe having someone to check in with? Like, someone who can help me stay accountable.
That’s a great idea. Having support can make a big difference. Would you like us to schedule regular check-ins to see how you’re doing with these changes?
Yeah, that would help. I think knowing I have someone to talk to about it would make it easier.
Absolutely. We’re in this together, and I’m here to support you every step of the way. Let’s start with cutting back on soda this week and see how that goes. How does that sound?
That sounds good. I think I can do that. Thanks for helping me break it down—it feels a little less overwhelming now.

You’re very welcome. Remember, change is a process, and it’s okay to take it one step at a time. You’re already taking a big step by being here and being willing to make changes. I’m looking forward to seeing your progress.
What else has brought you here today?
They found a little bag of weed on me.
I see. How are you feeling about that?
I mean, it’s not a big deal. It’s just a little bit.
So, it’s not a lot, and it sounds like it’s something you don’t see as a huge issue?
Yeah, exactly. It’s not like I was gonna sell it or anything. It’s just for me.
Got it. So, it’s more for personal use, and you don’t feel like it’s a major concern?
Yeah, I mean, it’s California. Everyone does it. No one really cares.
That’s true—it’s legal here. But I’m curious, how do you feel about being here today?
I just wanna get this over with, you know?
It sounds like you’re focused on moving forward and putting this behind you. Is that right?
Yeah, exactly. I just wanna do what I need to do and move on.
That makes sense. It’s important to you to get this resolved. How do you see this process helping you?
I don’t know. I guess just getting it done so I don’t have to deal with it anymore.
Okay. So, it’s about finding a way to close this chapter for you. Would it be helpful if we worked together to figure out what steps might make that happen?
Yeah, I guess so.
Great. I have a form we can use to map out some ideas together—kind of like a roadmap for our sessions. Would you be open to that?
Sure, why not.
Perfect. Let’s start by exploring what’s most important to you right now. What would you like to focus on first?
I don’t know. Maybe just figuring out how to get this whole thing over with.
That’s a good starting point. Let’s break it down. What do you think might help you feel like you’re making progress?
I guess just knowing what I need to do and doing it.
That sounds like a clear plan. Let’s work on identifying those steps together. How does that sound?
Yeah, that works.
Great. I’m here to support you in this process. Let’s take it one step at a time.
Sarah, I’m really glad you came in today. We’ve covered a lot, but I’d like to ask you a bit more about your smoking. Is that okay?
Yeah, sure.
Great. You mentioned earlier that your smoking has increased a bit. About how many cigarettes are you smoking in a day now?
Um, I guess… once in the morning, once during lunch, and then maybe five or six in the evening.
Okay, so around eight cigarettes a day—just under half a pack. Has this been a recent change?
Yeah, over the past year or so. It’s been creeping up.
I see. And it sounds like most of that increase is in the evenings?
Yeah. I have a two-year-old, so I wait until he’s asleep. It’s my time to unwind.
That makes sense. You’ve got a lot on your plate—working full-time, night classes, and being a mom. It’s understandable you’d want that time to relax.
Exactly. It’s my only real downtime.
What else do you do in the evenings to unwind?
Sometimes I’ll have a drink or two.
Got it. About how many drinks would you say you have in a week?
I don’t know… maybe two a day, max? But honestly, I’m not here to talk about drinking.
I completely understand, Sarah. My goal isn’t to judge or tell you what to do. I’m here to listen and share information so you can make the best decisions for your health. Does that sound okay?
Yeah, I guess.
Thanks. We know smoking and drinking can impact health, and I want to make sure you have all the resources you need to feel your best. What are your thoughts on that?
I mean, I don’t think I smoke or drink that much compared to other people. I’ve actually been trying to cut back.

That’s great to hear—you’re already making an effort. If you don’t mind, I’d like to use a readiness ruler. On a scale of 0 to 10, where 0 is not ready to quit at all and 10 is totally ready, where would you say you are?
Hmm… maybe a five?
A five—that’s a good starting point. What makes you say five instead of a lower number?
Well, you mentioned cancer risks, and as a mom, I don’t want to risk my health.
That’s really important—your health matters, not just for you but for your family too. What do you think might help you move closer to a 10?
I could try cutting back in the evenings. Maybe smoke three instead of five or six.
That’s a big step! Cutting back by half is a great goal. How about we check in again in four weeks to see how it’s going?
Sure, that works.
Perfect. We’ll review your lab results then, too. Would you like some information on quitting smoking?
Yeah, that’d be helpful.
Here’s a brochure with some tips, like distraction techniques for cravings. Many patients have found it useful. Also, would you be open to talking with one of our counselors?
What for?
Dr. Kirtley specializes in stress and alcohol use. Since you mentioned stress and having a couple of drinks to unwind, he could help you explore healthier ways to manage it. What do you think?
I’d be open to talking about stress, but I’m not sure about the drinking part.

That’s totally fine. Let’s set up an appointment with Dr. Kirtley to focus on stress, and we’ll see how it goes. Before you leave, we’ll schedule your next visit with me and the counseling session. Does that sound good?
Yeah, that works.
Great. It was really nice meeting you, Sarah. I’ll see you in four weeks!
Thanks. See you then.
Hi, Mrs. Smith. Thanks for coming in today. We’re scheduled to give Lilly some vaccines. How are you feeling about that?
Oh, um… I’m not sure. I’ve been reading a lot about vaccines lately, and I’m a little worried.
I hear that. It’s great that you’re looking into this—it shows how much you care about Lilly’s health. What specifically has been on your mind?
Well, I’ve read that it’s better for kids to build up their immunity naturally, you know, through their own immune systems.
That’s an interesting perspective. So, you’re thinking that natural exposure to illnesses might be a safer or more effective way for Lilly to build immunity?
Yeah, exactly. Like, I had chickenpox as a kid, and now I’m immune. So, isn’t that better?

That makes sense. Having chickenpox did give you natural immunity, and that’s one way the body can protect itself. Would it be okay if I shared some information about how vaccines work and why they’re recommended?
Sure, I guess. I just want to make sure I’m doing the right thing for her.

Of course, and that’s exactly what we’re here to figure out together. Before vaccines were available, many children got very sick from diseases like measles, polio, and whooping cough. Some even died or had lifelong disabilities, like paralysis or brain damage. Vaccines were developed to protect kids from those risks.
Wow, I didn’t realize it was that serious. I’ve never even heard of polio.

That’s actually a good thing—it means vaccines have been so effective that many of these diseases are rare now. But because of that, it’s easy to forget how dangerous they can be. How does this information sit with you?
I mean, I guess it makes sense. I just want Lilly to be healthy and safe. I don’t want to take any chances with her.

That’s completely understandable. It’s clear how much you care about her well-being. Vaccines are one way to help protect her from those serious risks. How do you feel about moving forward with them today?
I think it’s okay. I just want to do what’s best for her.

That’s a great mindset. It’s always good to ask questions and make informed decisions. You’re doing a wonderful job as a parent, Mrs. Smith. Let’s take it step by step, and I’m here to answer any other questions you might have.
So, I hear your overall goal is to not give up the things you enjoy but to cut back on how much you have. Is that right?
Yeah, that’s pretty much it. I don’t want to completely stop, but I need to find a better balance.

That makes sense. It sounds like this is really important to you. On a scale of 0 to 10, where 0 is not at all confident and 10 is extremely confident, how confident are you right now about starting this new plan?
Hmm, I’d say about a six.
A six. That’s a good starting point. What makes it a six and not lower?
Well, I’ve wanted to make this change for a long time. Ever since I was a teenager, I’ve been conscious of my health and how I feel in my body.
That’s a long time to carry this goal. What’s kept it alive for you all these years?

I think it’s because I’ve always admired my friends who are really active and healthy. They play soccer, hike, and just seem so energetic. I want to feel that way too—not necessarily to look like them, but to feel strong and confident in myself.
That’s a powerful motivation—wanting to feel strong and confident. What would it mean to you to achieve that?
It would mean everything. I’d feel like I’m finally taking control of my life and doing something for myself.

It’s been tough sometimes, but I’ve been focusing on my new friends and the breathing exercises you taught me.

I feel more in control. It’s like I’m taking charge of my emotions instead of letting them take over.

That’s such a powerful shift. It sounds like you’ve made some really meaningful changes—new friends, healthier coping strategies, and setting boundaries with people from your past. How do you feel about the progress you’ve made so far?
I feel proud. It hasn’t been easy, but I’m starting to see the benefits of these changes.
You should feel proud. Three months is a huge accomplishment, and it sounds like you’re building a strong foundation for the future. What’s next for you as you keep moving forward?
I want to keep focusing on my new friendships and maybe explore some new hobbies or activities to stay busy and positive.

That sounds like a great plan. Exploring new hobbies can be a fun way to stay engaged and build a fulfilling life. Let me know if you’d like help brainstorming ideas or finding resources to support you.

Of course. You’re doing amazing work, and I’m here to support you every step of the way. Let’s check in again soon to see how things are going. Sound good?
Sounds good. Thanks!
Thank you for coming in today. How are you feeling?
I feel great, actually.
That’s wonderful to hear. What’s contributing to that feeling?
I’ve been reflecting a lot, and I feel like I’m in a good place right now.
That’s great. I know you recently did your value clarification exercise. What were your top five values?
Yes, it was a really eye-opening experience. My number one value was self-respect, which surprised me because I don’t think it’s ever been in my top five before.
Really? That’s interesting. Do you have any idea why self-respect has become so important to you now?

I think it’s because I’ve realized how much I’ve neglected myself over the years. I’ve always put others first, almost to the point where I didn’t even consider my own needs. It was a bit of a sad realization, but also empowering because I know it’s never too late to change.
That’s such a powerful insight. How does it feel to prioritize yourself now?

It feels liberating. I’ve always thought that putting others first made me a better person, but I’ve realized that neglecting myself only leads to stress, resentment, and burnout. When I respect myself, I’m actually better for others too.
That’s such a healthy perspective. It sounds like you’ve been carrying a lot of concern about what others think. How has that influenced your actions in the past?

Completely. I’ve always let what I thought others wanted dictate my actions, rather than listening to my own values. It’s been that way since I was a child, and I didn’t even realize it until recently.
That’s a huge realization. How does it feel to finally see that pattern?

It’s like a celebration. I used to dwell on my childhood and all the things I didn’t get, but now I see that I can give myself what I need. I can be my own parent, my own advocate. It’s the first time I’ve said that without feeling guilty.
That’s incredible. It’s not selfish to prioritize yourself—it’s necessary. How does this shift make you feel overall?
Jubilant, joyful, and hopeful. I feel like I matter, like I count. I’m excited to pursue what I want with more passion and less dread.
That’s such a positive shift. What about your other top values? How do they connect to this new perspective?
My second value is inner harmony. I’ve realized that I need to be at peace with myself before I can truly connect with others. When I’m unhappy, it spills over into my relationships.
That makes so much sense. Inner harmony seems like the foundation for everything else. What about family happiness?
Yes, that’s my third value. When I’m at peace with myself, it naturally contributes to my family’s happiness. But when I neglect myself, I end up resentful and quarrelsome.
It sounds like self-respect and inner harmony are key to creating a positive environment for yourself and your family. What about your other values?
Health and achievement are also in my top five. Achievement, for me, is about a sense of accomplishment. I want to feel like I’m making a meaningful impact, not just going through the motions.
That’s such a fulfilling way to look at it. It’s not just about showing up—it’s about making a real difference. How does that tie into your work as a teacher and counselor?
Exactly. I could just show up and do the bare minimum, but that wouldn’t fulfill me. I want to give something meaningful, even if it’s small.
That’s such a beautiful perspective. It’s clear that these values are guiding you toward a healthier, more fulfilling life. Is there anything else that stood out to you during this exercise?

Yes, I was surprised that creativity and freedom didn’t make my top five this time. I realized that self-respect and inner harmony actually give me the freedom and creativity I’ve been seeking. When I’m at peace, the ideas flow naturally.
That’s such a profound connection. It sounds like this exercise has been transformative for you. How do you feel about where you are right now?
I feel like I’m on the right path. It’s been a journey, but I’m finally starting to feel like myself again.
That’s amazing to hear. Thank you so much for sharing your insights today. It’s been such a meaningful conversation.
Thank you for listening. It’s been really helpful to talk through all of this.
I don’t know, I’m just having a lot of trouble trying to lose the rest of the weight. No matter how much I exercise or run, nothing seems to be working.
It sounds like you’ve hit a plateau, and despite all your efforts, the scale isn’t moving. That must feel really frustrating.
Yes, exactly. I keep trying, but nothing’s happening. I don’t know what I’m doing wrong.
It sounds like you’re putting in a lot of effort, but the results aren’t matching up. How does that make you feel?
It’s discouraging. I’ll go to the gym, work hard, and then come home feeling like it’s all for nothing. And when I try to talk to my mom or dad about it, they don’t seem to care or support me.
So, not only are you feeling stuck, but you also feel like you’re doing this all alone?
Yes. It’s like no one understands or wants to help. My dad, especially, he doesn’t support me at all. In fact, he thinks I should be gaining weight back.
That sounds really tough. Can you tell me more about what your dad says or how he reacts?
He thinks that by losing weight, I’m trying to disconnect from our family or fit into some “perfect American” image. But that’s not it at all—I just want to be healthy and feel good about my body.
It sounds like there’s a disconnect between what you’re trying to achieve and how your family, especially your dad, sees it. How does that affect you?
It’s frustrating because I’m not doing this for anyone else—I’m doing it for me. But it feels like they don’t understand or respect that.
That must feel really isolating. It’s hard when the people closest to you don’t seem to support your goals. What do you think is driving your dad’s perspective?
I think it’s cultural. In our family, being bigger is seen as normal, and losing weight is almost like rejecting that. But for me, it’s not about rejecting my family—it’s about taking care of myself.
That’s such an important distinction. It sounds like you’re trying to balance your personal health goals with your family’s cultural values. How do you feel about navigating that tension?
It’s hard. I don’t want to feel like I’m turning my back on my family, but I also don’t want to give up on my health.
It’s a tough spot to be in. What do you think would help you feel more supported in your journey?
I think just having someone to talk to who understands would help. Maybe someone who’s been through something similar or who can help me stay motivated.
That’s a great idea. Have you thought about finding a support group or connecting with others who share your goals?
I haven’t, but that might help. It’s just hard to know where to start.
I can help you explore some options if you’d like. In the meantime, how do you feel about the progress you’ve made so far, even if the scale isn’t moving right now?
I guess I have made some progress. I feel stronger and more energetic, even if the weight isn’t coming off.

That’s a huge win. Sometimes progress isn’t just about the number on the scale—it’s about how you feel and the habits you’re building. How can you celebrate those wins, even if your family isn’t recognizing them?
I could try to focus more on how I feel and less on what the scale says. Maybe keeping a journal or tracking my energy levels could help me see the bigger picture.

Hi, Andrea. Thanks for coming in today. I usually meet with students once or twice a semester to talk about life, goals, and behaviors. How are you doing?
I’m good, thanks.
Great. Let’s start by you telling me a little about yourself.
Sure. My name’s Andrea. I’m in the marching band—I play the tenor sax. I’m also in jazz band and wind ensemble. I’m an IB student too.
That’s impressive! How long have you been playing the sax?
About four years, but I’ve been involved in music for about 10 years total. I started with the violin, then clarinet, and finally found my way to the sax.
Wow, that’s a lot of experience. How do you like marching band?
It’s fun but a lot of work. I love the group setting and working with my classmates. Competitions are really exciting.
That sounds rewarding. Do you have friends in band, or do you hang out with others outside of band?
I have two groups—friends from class and friends from band.
Got it. Tell me a little about your family.
I have an older brother who’s nine years older than me, my parents, and our golden retriever, Charlie. He’s eight.
Sounds like a great family. What are your plans after high school?
I want to go to college and become a doctor—maybe in psychology or psychiatry.
That’s an amazing goal. Have you thought about specific schools or majors?
Not too much yet. I’m thinking psychology, but I haven’t narrowed it down.
That’s okay—you’ve got time. How are your grades?
They’re pretty good—high three-point something.
That’s great. What do you like to do for fun on weekends?
Usually hang out with friends—movies or just chilling at someone’s house.
When you’re hanging out, is there ever alcohol involved?
Sometimes, yeah. I’ll be honest—it depends on how much schoolwork I have. If there’s less, it might be every other weekend or three weekends a month.
How much do you usually drink when you do?
Not enough to get blackout drunk—just a little tipsy. I’ve gotten blackout drunk once, but I didn’t like it, so I avoid that now.
Got it. How much do your friends drink?
About the same—one or two drinks, but sometimes more.
Andrea, based on what you’ve shared, your drinking puts you in a high-risk group. Have you thought about the risks?
Not really. I figured since we’re in a small group and usually sleep over, we avoid things like drinking and driving or unsafe situations.
That’s good, but there are still risks like health problems, accidents, or even developing alcoholism. How do you feel about that?
I haven’t thought much about it, but it’s a little concerning now that you mention it.
I’m glad you’re open to discussing it. What would it take for you to cut back or stop drinking?
I think I could stop. I don’t need it—it’s more about the social aspect. But it might be hard if my friends are still drinking.
That’s a valid concern. How do you think your close friends would react if you decided not to drink?
My close friends would probably be supportive, but the ones I’m not as close with might judge me.
It sounds like your close friends are the ones who matter most. How about focusing on spending more time with them and less with the others?
That makes sense. I could try that.
Great. Let’s set a goal for you to stop drinking, starting this weekend. How does that sound?
I think I can do it, especially if I focus on band and my close friends.
That’s a great plan. What will you say if someone asks why you’re not drinking?
I could say I’m focusing on school and my health, and I don’t want to risk my future.
Perfect. You could even encourage them to cut back too. How do you feel about this plan?
I feel good about it. It’s a step in the right direction.
I’m proud of you for taking this seriously. Let’s check in again in a couple of weeks to see how it’s going.
Sounds good. Thanks for your help.
You’re welcome, Andrea. I’m here to support you. Take care!

No.

Sure.

Yeah.

It’s not a big deal. Sometimes I drink with friends—beers or rum and cokes at parties.
How much do you usually drink at a time?
Maybe three or four drinks. I don’t really keep track.
And how often does this happen?
About once or twice a month.
How long have you been drinking like this?
Since last October, so about six months.
What do you like about drinking?
It’s fun hanging out with friends, especially at parties. I like the taste too.
So it helps you relax and have fun. Are there any parts of drinking you don’t like?
I hate the hangovers—feeling sick and throwing up the next morning.
Have you ever had a blackout, where you couldn’t remember what happened?
No, but I know someone who has.
Have you had any problems because of drinking, like at school or home?
I missed first period once because of a hangover. My mom got mad and grounded me for two weeks.
That sounds tough. Have you told your mom about your drinking?
No, but she figured it out when I couldn’t get out of bed that morning.
So drinking has caused some issues, like missing school and getting in trouble at home.
Yeah, but it’s only happened once.
I see you marked that you haven’t ridden with someone who was drinking or driven after drinking. That’s great. I hope you keep avoiding those situations.
Yeah, I will.

Okay.

Probably a five.

I’m tired of getting in trouble.
What could you do to avoid trouble?
Not drink.
Have you ever tried stopping?
Not really.
Some people your age try stopping for a while to see how it feels. Could you try that?
Yeah, I could.
How long do you think you could go without drinking?
Maybe two months.
What would make it easier for you to stop drinking?
I could drink something else, like coke, when my friends are drinking. Or hang out with friends who don’t drink.
That’s a great plan. Do you have anyone who could support you in this?
My friends who don’t drink would probably be happy and supportive.

You’ve come up with good reasons to stop—like avoiding hangovers and trouble—and solid strategies, like spending time with non-drinking friends. I’m proud of you for considering this. How about we schedule a follow-up in two months to see how it’s going?
Okay.
Great. I’ll see you then. Take care, Jacob.

It’s tough, but I know I need to do something about it. I can’t keep going like this.

I guess I’d have to be honest with them and explain why I’m cutting back. It won’t be easy, though.

Maybe we could talk about strategies for saying no or finding other ways to spend time with them.

Yeah, that would help. I feel like I’m ready to take this seriously.
That’s fantastic to hear. Let’s work on a plan to help you move forward.

Hi, Laura. So, thanks for coming in. I'm not sure how much you know about why you're here or what we're supposed to talk about. Um, I think all my grades are A's and B's, so, yeah.

Um, I'm not sure yet, but I'm looking into schools like in the area, so maybe, I don't know, maybe I'll leave home or something.
Okay. Cool. And, you know, what made you decide maybe law school or-or journalism?
Um, well, I'm definitely not a math or science person, so I started off by there that I started looking at careers that maybe I would like. So-

Okay. Great. Sounds like you have, like I said, really good goals and you're working hard in school. Um, you said that when you're going out with your friends, you like to hang out and shop and stuff like that and also go to parties, so do you drink alcohol?
Um, not really. Maybe one or two drinks at a party at the most.

Um, maybe like once or twice a month at the most.

Yeah.

Possibly, yeah.

Yeah, I guess you can say that.

Um, just two drinks at a party at the most. I don't-- I don't like to drink a lot. I don't-- Getting drunk is not something that appeals to me. So, I just have, like, a drink in my hand, so my friends won't bug me about not drinking. It's just like to look like I'm actually doing something. Most of- a lot of the time, I don't even drink at all. So-
But you've been drunk before?
Um, no, not really, maybe tipsy, but not like drunk.
Okay. Um, so the most you've ever, ever had is two drinks in a day.
Yeah.
Okay. Interesting. So, do you know all the bad stuff about alcohol?
Um, yeah, yeah.

Okay. Um, so one of the things that, you know, is really important to talk to teenagers about is drinking and driving. So, um, you know, that's actually a really big problem. And even around here, we have kids die every year from getting in a drunk driving accident. So that's something that you really need to make sure you're not doing, all right? Have you ever done that? Have you ever gotten in the car-
No, I have drunk-driven and never got in a car with a drunk driver.
Okay. Uh, how much do your friends drink?

Um, I mean, I have some friends that drink some more than others, like, my close group of friends don't really drink as much because I'm not really interested in that, but I know that there are people that drink a lot more.
Okay. What about at these parties you're going to, are there other kids there who are drinking a lot?
Yeah. There are kids that drink a lot more than I do. Definitely, yeah.
And do you hang out with them?
Not really closely, like, I know who they are and I'll say hi, but not-- They're not really, like, close friends of mine.
Mm-hmm, so, you know, even just hanging out around kids who are drinking a lot actually puts you at a lot more risk. Did you know that?
Um, yeah. That makes sense.

Yeah, so, there, I mean, a lot of the other dangers of drinking, like, um, not just car accidents, but you can have other accidents, you know, people, um, you know, will fall or, um, you know, break things or a lot of people actually end up breaking their bones and ending up in the emergency room because they've been drunk and falling down or, you know, as a girl, it's really important too that you're careful because you could be sexually assaulted.
Yeah.
You know, especially if you've been drinking, then, you know, you're at a lot more risk because a guy can take advantage of you. Did- have you thought about that?
Yeah, yeah, I have. That's, uh, one of the main reasons that I don't like to drink that much.
Mm-hmm.
So-

And then, um, you know, people get in fights more often when they've been drinking too. Um, also, you know, there have been a lot of kids, even at this school, who've gotten in trouble because they were drinking and someone took pictures with their cell phone and put it up on Facebook-
Yeah.

And then their parents find out or the school finds out and, you know, we have a no-tolerance policy here about drugs and alcohol, and really can get you into trouble, and it could put your whole college career in jeopardy. Have you thought about that?
Yeah. Definitely, yeah.
But you're still drinking.
Um, yeah, I mean, I guess it's the thing to do at a party, so-
Uh-huh. So, I mean, do you think it's the thing to do if you wanna be an attorney?
Um, definitely not. That's why I don't try to drink that much. Just-
Mm-hmm.
-make it look like I am, kind of.
Mm-hmm. Okay. Hmm. So, I mean, I guess what we need to do then is kinda talk about some goals for how to be-
Okay.
safer.
Okay.

I definitely agree. I know that there are some other risks involved in alcohol, they are the ones you mentioned, like, health-wise and things like that, so, I agree that alcohol may not be the best thing.
Mm-hmm. So, do you think you can quit?
Um, yeah, I mean, it's not, like, a really big part of my life, so.
Okay. So, I'm going to write down then that you've decided to quit.
Okay.

And, um, that's gonna be your goal, and that's great, you know, that's really why we're here, is to talk about that and-and make sure that you come to that decision. Um, so, I guess, can you quit this weekend then?
Yeah, yeah, definitely. I'll just not have a drink.
Okay, and then what about your friends who are still drinking?
Um, I really can't control what they do, but I'll definitely try to get my closest friends to maybe stop like I will.
Okay, and-and what if they won't?
Well, then, I guess, I'll just try to hang around them less or something. I'll try to find things for us to do that don't involve alcohol like a party or anything.
Yeah. Probably if your friends won't quit drinking, you should just find new friends.
Okay.

'Cause, you know, the problem is if they're drinking, they're gonna pressure you into drinking and then you're gonna feel awkward and, you know, you're gonna be stuck and-and not know what to do and really you'd just be better off probably without them. Yeah.
-they're probably not a good influence.
Okay, yeah.

Um, and then, then you'll be better set for college too because, you know, the issue is you're getting good grades now, but when you get to college, it's a lot harder and, you know, if you're needing really good grades to get into law school, which you will need, then you really can't be distracted by alcohol.
Okay, yeah, definitely.

Uh, no.
like that?

Hi, Mrs. Smith. I’m Denise, one of the social workers here at the clinic. I work closely with Dr. Fields and the team to support people in situations like yours—especially those transitioning back home after rehab. How has it been since you returned home?
It’s been pretty good, overall.
That’s great to hear! What’s been the best part about being back home?
Oh, I’m so glad to see my dog again—he’s such a sweetheart. And my garden is coming along nicely. It just feels good to be home.

That sounds wonderful. Being back in your own space, surrounded by what you love, must feel really rewarding. I know getting home was a big goal for you. How have you been managing with your physical therapy and Tai Chi?
Well… I didn’t go this week.
Oh? What happened that led you to skip them?
I had a bit of a scare—I didn’t fully fall, but I lost my balance. It made me think maybe I’m pushing myself too hard.

That sounds really unsettling. It’s understandable to feel cautious after something like that. You’ve been working so hard to get home and stay active—it’s a lot to manage. What’s been going through your mind since that happened?
I’m worried I might fall again. If I hurt myself, I might not be able to stay home anymore. That’s the last thing I want.
It sounds like staying home is really important to you, and you’re trying to figure out how to balance staying safe with staying active. What do you think might help you feel more secure?
I don’t know… maybe cutting back on Tai Chi? It feels like it’s too much right now.
That’s a valid concern. Tai Chi can be demanding, and it’s okay to reassess what feels right for you. Do you remember what Dr. Fields said about Tai Chi and its benefits for preventing falls?
She did mention that it helps with balance and preventing falls. But after what happened, I’m not so sure it’s for me.
It’s okay to feel unsure. It sounds like you’re weighing the benefits against how it feels for you personally. What would it take for you to feel safe enough to try it again, even in a modified way?
I guess if I knew I had some backup—like a way to call for help if something happened. I live alone, and that’s been on my mind a lot.

That’s a really important point. Many people find peace of mind with a personal emergency response system, like a lifeline button. It’s a small device you can wear that connects you to help instantly. Would something like that ease your concerns?
Yes, that sounds like it could help. I’ve seen those on TV, but I wasn’t sure if they really worked.
They do! And they’re designed to give you that sense of security. What else might help you feel more supported at home?
Maybe a refresher on home safety tips? And some kind of support system—like a buddy or someone to check in with. My daughter calls, but she lives far away, and I don’t want to burden my neighbors.
Those are great ideas. We can arrange for a caseworker to visit and go over home safety with you. They can also help connect you with local resources or support groups. How does that sound?
That would be really helpful. I feel like I’ve taken a few steps back lately, and I need to get back on track.
It’s completely normal to feel that way after a setback. You’ve already shown so much strength and determination to get this far. What’s motivating you to keep going?
My home, my dog, my garden—they mean everything to me. I’ve lived here for decades, and I’m not ready to give it up.

That’s such a powerful motivator. It’s clear how much your home and independence mean to you. Let’s work together to create a plan that helps you stay safe and active while honoring what matters most to you. Does that sound like a good next step?
Yes, it does. Thank you for listening and helping me figure this out.
Of course! You’re doing such important work, and I’m here to support you every step of the way. Let’s get started on those next steps so you can feel more confident and secure at home.
Hi, Mr. Johnson. I’m here to talk with you about your cholesterol and the medication your doctor prescribed. How are you feeling about everything?
Honestly, I’m not sure I’m going to take the medicine. I know my cholesterol is high, but I’m worried about the side effects.

It sounds like you’re feeling torn. On one hand, you know your cholesterol needs to come down, but on the other, you’re concerned about how the medication might affect you. Can you tell me more about what’s on your mind?
Yeah, I’m a truck driver, and I haul heavy boxes all day. I can’t afford to have muscle weakness—it would ruin my job.

That makes a lot of sense. Your job is physically demanding, and you need to stay strong and healthy to keep doing it. What has your doctor told you about the risks of not treating your high cholesterol?
He said I could be at risk for a stroke or heart attack down the line, but that’s not happening right now. The muscle weakness, though—that could happen right away.

I hear you. It’s tough to weigh the risks of something that might happen in the future against something that could affect your job right now. Have you talked with your doctor about your concerns with the medication?
Not really. He just said I need to take it.

I see. It sounds like you’re feeling a bit stuck—you want to lower your cholesterol, but you’re worried about how the medication might impact your ability to work. What would help you feel more comfortable about starting the medication?
I don’t know. Maybe if I knew for sure that the muscle weakness wouldn’t happen, or if there was a way to manage it if it did.

That’s a really good point. The side effect you’re worried about is actually very rare, and if it does happen, it’s usually mild and reversible. Your doctor can monitor you closely and adjust the medication if needed. How does that sound to you?
I guess that’s better, but I’m still not sure. What if it happens at a bad time, like when I’m on the road?

That’s a valid concern. If you do experience any muscle weakness, it’s important to let your doctor know right away so they can help you manage it. In the meantime, starting the medication could significantly lower your risk of a stroke or heart attack, which could have a much bigger impact on your ability to work and live the way you want to. How do you feel about that trade-off?
I mean, I don’t want to have a stroke or anything, but I just don’t want to risk my job either.

It’s clear how much your job means to you, and it’s important to protect that. At the same time, managing your cholesterol is about protecting your long-term health so you can keep doing what you love. What would it take for you to feel ready to give the medication a try?
I guess if I knew I could stop it if something went wrong, I’d feel better about trying it.
That’s a great plan. You can start the medication, and if you notice any issues, you can let your doctor know right away. They can adjust or switch the medication if needed. How does that sound?
Yeah, that sounds okay. I’ll give it a try.

That’s a big step, and I’m glad you’re willing to give it a shot. Let’s make sure you have all the information you need, and feel free to reach out if you have any concerns along the way. Does that work for you?
Yeah, that works. Thanks for listening.
Of course! Your health and your job are both important, and we’re here to support you in finding the right balance. Let’s get you started on the medication, and we’ll take it one step at a time.
Hi, Mrs. Smith. My name is Terri, and I’m one of the nurses who works with Dr. Fields. How are you doing today?
I remember you. Yeah, we met once before.
That’s right—last time you were here. I wanted to check in with you about the Tai Chi class Dr. Fields recommended. How did that go?
Well, I went once.
Uh-huh. What was your experience like?
It was beautiful to watch, and the instructor was very nice. But I felt really self-conscious because I had to sit in a chair with my walker. I couldn’t do what everyone else was doing.
It sounds like you enjoyed the atmosphere and the instructor, but feeling self-conscious made it hard to fully engage. Is that right?
Yes, exactly. I felt really out of place.
That’s completely understandable. What were you hoping to achieve by going to Tai Chi?
Dr. Fields said it could help with my balance. I’m still struggling with the “wobblies,” and I was hoping it would help me feel more stable.
So, you were looking for something to help with your balance, but you didn’t see the results you were hoping for after one session?
Not yet, no.
That makes sense. It can take time to see progress. What’s your overall goal right now? What are you working toward?
I want to go home.
Going home is really important to you. What is it about being at home that matters so much?
Everything. I miss my little dog, my garden, and just being independent—cooking for myself, sleeping and waking up when I want. I miss my life.
It sounds like home represents freedom, comfort, and the things you love. What do you think you need to do to achieve that goal of going home?
They told me I need to be able to walk down the hallway and back with my walker, without feeling unsteady. I’m not there yet.
And do you agree that’s what you need to work on to get home safely?
Yes, I do. I don’t want to fall. I’ve had friends who’ve fallen, and it didn’t end well. So, I agree—but it’s hard.
It’s clear that safety is a priority for you. How’s your physical therapy going?
It’s better. It still hurts, but I’m making progress. It’s not as painful as it used to be.
That’s great to hear. It sounds like you’re seeing some improvement there. And you were hoping Tai Chi could help with your balance too. Do you think you’d like to give it another try?
[sighs] Yes, I think so. My friend loves it, and I liked the instructor. I just wish I didn’t feel so self-conscious.
It’s okay to feel unsure after just one session. It sounds like you’re open to trying again, but the self-consciousness and the logistics of getting there are holding you back. Is that right?
Yes, exactly. Making the arrangements is complicated, and I feel so out of place in the class.
Let’s break that down. On a scale of 1 to 10, how confident are you that you can make the arrangements to get to Tai Chi again?
Maybe a 5. I know I can do it, but it’s really difficult on my own.
What would make it easier for you?
If I had some help—like someone to help me arrange transportation. My daughter could do it, but she can’t visit for at least a week.
Would it help if we arranged transportation for you? The rehab center has a van service for patients.
That would be amazing. Yes, please.
We can absolutely help with that. What about the self-consciousness? How do you think you could work through that?
I think I just need to remind myself that no one is really looking at me. It’s more in my head.
That’s a great insight. It’s normal to feel self-conscious, but you’re there for your own progress. Would it help to talk to the instructor beforehand and let them know how you’re feeling?
Yes, that might help.
Great. Let’s make those arrangements for you, and I’ll check in with you after your next session to see how it goes. How does that sound?
That sounds good. Thank you so much.
You’re welcome, Mrs. Smith. I’m really glad you’re willing to give it another try. You’re making great progress, and I’m here to support you every step of the way.

I’m really glad to hear that. How can I support you as you work on this?
Maybe we could check in every so often to see how it’s going?
Absolutely. I’m here to help. Let’s plan to talk again soon and see how things are progressing.
Sounds good. Thanks for listening.
Of course, Tommy. I’m proud of you for being open to this conversation. Let’s take it one step at a time.
Hi, Jean. I’m Dr. Selby. It’s great to meet you. How are you doing today?
Good morning, doctor. I’m okay, but honestly, I’ve been better.
I hear that. What’s been on your mind lately?
Well, I was diagnosed with COPD about three months ago, and it’s been really hard.
That sounds like a lot to process. How has it been for you since the diagnosis?
It’s been scary. I haven’t felt well for a while, and I know I need to quit smoking, but it’s so hard.
It sounds like you’re feeling overwhelmed. What made you decide to come in today?
I realized I can’t keep going like this. I need help to quit smoking for good.
That’s a big step, Jean. What makes quitting smoking important to you right now?
My health is getting worse, and I’m scared. I don’t want to end up in the hospital again.
It sounds like your health is a top priority for you. What else worries you about smoking?
It’s expensive, and I’ve noticed it’s affecting my appearance too—my skin, my nails, everything.
So, it’s impacting your health, your finances, and even how you feel about yourself. That’s a lot.
Yeah, it’s just too much. I know I need to stop, but I don’t know if I can.
It’s okay to feel unsure. Change is hard. What’s made you feel like you might not be able to quit?
I’ve tried before—pills, patches, therapy—but nothing worked. I even quit for a week in the hospital, but I started again right after.
It sounds like you’ve put in a lot of effort already. What helped you quit during that week in the hospital?
I didn’t have a choice—I couldn’t smoke there. But once I got out, it was like I couldn’t stop myself.
That makes sense. It’s tough when smoking feels like such a big part of your life. What do you enjoy about smoking?
It’s been part of my life since I was a teenager. It helps me relax, and it’s something I do with friends and family.
So, it’s not just a habit—it’s tied to your relationships and how you cope with stress. That’s a lot to let go of.
Exactly. It’s like giving up a part of myself.
I can see how that feels overwhelming. What would you say is the hardest part about quitting for you?
Probably the social part. Everyone around me smokes, and it’s how we connect.
That’s a real challenge. What do you think could help you navigate that?
Maybe finding other ways to connect with people, or having someone to support me.
That’s a great insight. If you had that support, how do you think it would help?
I think it would make me feel less alone in this. Like I’m not the only one trying to quit.
That’s a really good point. Jean, on a scale of 1 to 10, how important is quitting smoking to you right now?
It’s a 10. I know I need to do this for my health and my future.
That’s a strong motivation. And how confident are you, from 1 to 10, that you can quit?
Maybe a 4. I want to believe I can, but I’m scared I’ll fail again.
It’s okay to feel that way. What do you think could help move that confidence from a 4 to a 5 or 6?
Maybe if I had a plan or some tools to help me cope when it gets hard.
That’s a great idea. Would you be open to trying something small this week, like tracking when and why you smoke?
I think I could do that. It might help me understand my triggers better.
That’s a great start. I can give you a simple tracker to use, and we can review it together next time. How does that sound?
That sounds good. It feels like a small step, but at least it’s something.
Exactly. Small steps lead to big changes. I’m really proud of you for taking this first step, Jean.
Thank you, doctor. I feel a little more hopeful already.
That’s wonderful to hear. I’ll see you next week, and we’ll take it from there.
Thank you so much. I’ll see you then.
So, we’ve touched on a few areas you’d like to work on—physical activity, nutrition, and body confidence. What feels most important to focus on today?

I think starting with physical activity makes the most sense. It feels like the easiest place to start. Nutrition feels a bit overwhelming right now, but if I can get into a routine with activity, it might help me tackle the other stuff later.

That sounds like a great plan. Starting with something manageable can build momentum. What’s motivating you to focus on physical activity right now? You’ve mentioned energy and mood—are there other reasons this feels important to you?

Yeah, definitely. I want to feel stronger, you know? Like, last night I struggled to open a jar of salsa, and it was so frustrating. I’d love to feel more capable in little ways like that. Plus, I think being more active would help my body confidence too.

That’s a really clear vision—feeling stronger, more capable, and more confident in your body. It sounds like those small, everyday wins, like opening a jar, really matter to you. How about your mood and energy? How do you see those fitting into this?

Oh, for sure. I’ve noticed that when I’m more active, I feel less irritable and more productive. It’s like a domino effect—better energy, better mood, and then I just feel better about myself overall.

That’s such a great connection. It sounds like physical activity could be a cornerstone for a lot of positive changes in your life. On a scale from 0 to 10, where 0 is “not ready at all” and 10 is “totally ready,” where would you say you are right now in terms of starting this change?
Hmm, I’d say I’m at an 8.
An 8—that’s pretty high! What’s keeping you from being at a 6 or lower?
Well, I’ve already thought about all the benefits—better mood, more energy, feeling stronger, and even improving how I see myself. Those things really make me want to get started.

It’s amazing how much clarity you have about the benefits. You’ve got a strong vision of what you want—energy, mood, strength, and body confidence. Is there anything else that’s motivating you that we haven’t touched on yet?
Not that I can think of. Those are the big ones for me right now.

Got it. It sounds like you’re really clear on your “why.” So, if you’re ready, we can start exploring what this might look like in practice. What kinds of activities do you think you’d enjoy or feel comfortable starting with?
Yeah, I’d love to talk about that. I think starting with something simple, like walking or maybe yoga, could work for me.
That’s a great starting point—something simple and enjoyable. Let’s dive into that a bit more. What would make those activities feel doable for you right now?
