Thank you for coming in today, Katie. How are you feeling about being here?
I’m okay, I guess. My doctor referred me, so I’m just doing what I’m told.
I see. It sounds like you’re here because your doctor has some concerns. Can you tell me more about that?
Yeah, he’s worried about my alcohol intake during pregnancy.
I understand. How do you feel about that concern?
Honestly, I don’t think it’s a big deal. I’ve heard mixed things, and I don’t see the risk.
So it sounds like you’re not too concerned, but your doctor is. Can you tell me a bit about your drinking habits?
Sure. I usually have a glass of wine with dinner. It’s just a way to relax, and it’s kind of a family tradition.
I hear that. It’s part of your routine and helps you unwind. Have you thought about how it might affect your pregnancy?
Not really. I’ve seen articles and heard from friends that it’s not a big deal. I think it’s kind of overblown.
It sounds like you’ve done some research and feel confident in your perspective. What do you think about the idea that there’s no safe amount of alcohol during pregnancy?
I don’t know. It feels like they’re just repeating the same thing without showing me real evidence.
So you’re looking for more concrete proof. What would help you feel more convinced?
I guess if I saw something that clearly showed the risks, I’d take it more seriously.
That makes sense. Would you be open to looking at some guidelines together?
Sure, I guess.
Great. According to the latest guidelines, there’s no safe amount of alcohol during pregnancy. It’s recommended to avoid it entirely. What are your thoughts on that?
I mean, I’ve heard that before, but I still don’t see the evidence. It’s hard to believe without more proof.
I hear your skepticism. It’s tough to change your perspective without feeling convinced. How important is it to you to have a healthy baby?
It’s really important. I want to be a good parent and do everything I can to protect my baby.
That’s a really strong value. It sounds like being a good parent means making choices that prioritize your baby’s health. How do you feel about aligning your actions with that goal?
I guess if it’s really necessary, I’d consider cutting back. But I’d need more information and support.
That’s a great step. What kind of support would help you make that change?
Maybe talking to my partner and finding ways to relax without alcohol. It’s just hard to imagine giving it up completely.
It’s a big adjustment, and it’s okay to feel that way. What if we explored some alternatives together and worked on a plan that feels manageable for you?
That sounds helpful. I’d like to learn more and see how I can make it work.
I’m glad to hear that. Let’s take this step by step. How about we meet again next week to discuss your progress and any questions you have?
Yeah, that works for me. Thanks for listening and not just telling me what to do.
Of course, Katie. This is about what works best for you. I’ll see you next week.
Well, Mr. Smith, it looks like we’ve got your medication sorted out. How are you feeling about that?
Good, yeah. It’s one less thing to worry about.
That’s great to hear. I did notice your blood pressure is a bit on the higher side today. How does that sit with you?
Yeah, I guess it’s not ideal, but I’ve been under a lot of pressure lately.
That makes sense. Stress can definitely play a role. I wonder if we could take a moment to talk about something related—your weight. How would you feel about that?
My weight? Seriously? I mean, I’ve already had to wait 45 minutes just to get in here.
I hear you. That wait must have been frustrating, especially when you’ve got a busy schedule. I really appreciate you sticking around.
Yeah, well, I’ve got clients waiting for me, accounts to sort out—it’s not like I can just drop everything.

Absolutely. It sounds like your time is really precious, and I don’t want to take up more of it than necessary. I just wanted to check in with you about your weight because it can sometimes tie into things like blood pressure and overall health. How does that land for you?
I mean, I get it. I know my weight’s not where it should be, but honestly, I don’t have the time to focus on that right now.
That’s fair. It sounds like you’re juggling a lot, and adding one more thing to the list might feel overwhelming. Can I ask—what’s your biggest concern about your weight at the moment?

Well, I know it’s not great for my health. I get out of breath easily, and I’m sure it’s not helping my blood pressure. But between work and everything else, it’s hard to find the energy to do anything about it.
It sounds like you’re aware of the impact it’s having, but the demands of your life make it tough to prioritize. What would it look like if things were a little different?
I guess I’d like to feel healthier, maybe have more energy. But it’s just not that simple. I’m always on the go—grabbing food here and there, no time to cook or exercise.
I hear that. It’s not easy to make changes when life feels so rushed. Let me ask you this—if you could make one small change that felt manageable, what might that be?
Hmm. Maybe I could try to cut back on the ready meals. But even that feels like a lot when I’m juggling everything else.
That’s a really thoughtful idea. Small steps can make a big difference over time. What would help you feel supported in making that kind of change?
I don’t know. Maybe if I had a bit more structure or someone to keep me on track. But like I said, time is the biggest issue.

Totally understandable. How about this—we could schedule a follow-up in a couple of weeks to check in on how you’re doing? I could also give you some quick tips for healthier eating on the go, if that would help.
Yeah, that might work. But I’d need an early appointment—I can’t afford to wait around again.
Of course. How about we book you in for the first slot of the day? That way, you can get in and out without any delays.
That sounds better. I’ll see if I can make it work.

Great. And in the meantime, maybe you could think about one or two small changes that feel doable for you. Even something as simple as swapping out one ready meal for a healthier option could be a start.
Yeah, I can try that. Thanks for understanding.
Absolutely. I know it’s not easy, but you’re already taking a step by being here today. Let’s touch base in a couple of weeks and see how things are going.
Okay, sounds good. Thanks.
Hi, Mike. Thanks for coming in today. I’m Kathy. How are you doing?
Hi, Kathy. I’m doing alright, thanks. Nice to meet you.
I appreciate you taking the time to be here. I know this might not be where you’d choose to spend your afternoon, so thank you for showing up. How are you feeling about being here today?
Honestly, I’m not sure what to expect. My lawyer said I needed to come, so here I am.

That makes sense. It can feel a bit uncertain when you’re not sure what’s ahead. Let’s take this step by step. First, how are you doing physically? I want to make sure you’re feeling okay before we dive into anything.
I’m fine, yeah. No issues there.
Good to hear. So, I understand you’re here because of a recent DUI. Can you tell me a little about what happened?
Yeah, I got a DUI a few weeks ago. I was speeding, and I blew a 2.8. It’s my second one, so I guess that’s why I’m here.
Thanks for sharing that. It sounds like this has been a challenging experience. How have you been feeling since it happened?
Honestly, I’ve been stressed. I don’t want to lose my license, and I’m worried about my job. I sell cars, so I need to drive for work.
That sounds really tough. It’s clear this situation is weighing on you. What have you been thinking about since the DUI?
I’ve been thinking I need to be more careful. Maybe not drink as much, or at least not drive if I’ve had anything.
That’s a really thoughtful reflection. It sounds like you’re considering some changes to avoid being in this situation again. What do you think those changes might look like for you?
Well, I’ve thought about calling a cab or having someone else drive if I’m going to drink. Or maybe just not drinking at all when I’m out.
Those sound like solid plans. It seems like you’ve put a lot of thought into this. What do you think would be the easiest change to start with?
Probably just not driving if I’ve had anything to drink. I think that’s the biggest thing.
That makes sense. It sounds like you’re really focused on keeping yourself and others safe. How confident do you feel about sticking to that plan?
I’d say I’m pretty confident. I don’t want to go through this again.
That’s great to hear. It sounds like you’re motivated to make a change. What do you think might get in the way of sticking to that plan?
Maybe my friends. They like to drink, and sometimes they give me a hard time if I’m not joining in.
That’s a good point. It can be tough when friends are part of the equation. How do you think you could handle that situation if it comes up?
I guess I could just tell them I’m not drinking, or maybe I’ll have one and stop. I don’t want to feel left out, but I also don’t want to get in trouble again.
It sounds like you’re balancing a lot—your friendships and your desire to stay safe. What do you think your friends would say if you told them you’re trying to cut back?
They’d probably tease me at first, but they’d get it. They’re my friends, after all.
That’s a good perspective. It sounds like you trust them to support you, even if it takes a little time. How do you think making these changes might impact your life?
I think it’d be better overall. I wouldn’t have to worry about getting in trouble, and I’d feel better about myself.
That’s a really positive outlook. It sounds like you’re seeing the benefits of making these changes. What’s one small step you could take this week to move in that direction?
Maybe I’ll just plan ahead if I’m going out—like, set aside money for a cab or ask a friend to be the designated driver.
That’s a great plan. It sounds like you’re ready to take action. I’m really impressed by how much thought you’ve put into this. How can I support you as you move forward?
I think just having someone to talk to about it helps. It’s good to get it all out there.
I’m glad you feel that way. You’re doing important work here, Mike. Let’s check in next time and see how things are going. Does that sound good?
Yeah, that works for me. Thanks, Kathy.
You’re welcome, Mike. Thanks for being so open today. Take care, and I’ll see you soon.
Steve, before we wrap up today, I’d like to spend a few minutes discussing your drinking habits. How does that sound?
Sure, I guess. What do you want to know?
Thanks for being open to this. I noticed on the survey you filled out that you mentioned drinking 2-3 times a week, with 3-4 drinks each time. Does that sound about right?
Yeah, that’s accurate. Mostly on weekends.

Got it. I wanted to share that I’m a bit concerned about your drinking level. It can sometimes worsen or even cause health issues, like the anxiety and insomnia you mentioned earlier. Have you ever thought about how drinking might be connected to those?
Not really. I don’t think I drink enough for it to be a problem. If anything, I sleep better when I drink.

That’s a common belief, and you’re not alone in thinking that. While alcohol might help you fall asleep faster, it can disrupt your sleep later in the night, causing you to wake up around 2 or 3 AM. Does that sound familiar?
Huh. Yeah, I do wake up around then sometimes. I didn’t realize it could be from drinking.

It’s a tricky effect. Let me show you this chart. For men under 65, low-risk drinking is no more than 14 drinks a week and no more than 4 drinks a day. Based on your survey, you’re in the high-risk category. How does that land for you?
Wow, I didn’t realize I was in that category. I don’t think of myself as a heavy drinker.
It can be surprising to see it laid out like this. On a scale of 1 to 10, where 1 is “I don’t want to change” and 10 is “I’m ready to change,” where would you say you are?
Hmm. I guess I’d say a 5. I mean, I don’t want to put my health at risk, but I also don’t think I’m that bad.
A 5 is a great starting point. What makes you choose 5 instead of a lower number?
Well, I’m training for a marathon, and I need to be at my best. But I still don’t think I’m a problem drinker.
That makes sense. Your health and marathon training are important to you, and you were surprised to see where your drinking falls on the chart. What do you think you might want to do about it?
I guess I could cut back a little. Maybe drink less often or have fewer drinks when I do.
That’s a thoughtful approach. What would cutting back look like for you?
Maybe limit myself to 3-4 drinks on weekends and cut back to drinking only twice a week.
That’s a solid plan. Writing it down can help make it feel more concrete. If you were to set a goal for yourself, what would it be?
I’d say no more than 18 drinks a week.

That’s a step in the right direction. While 18 is still above the low-risk level, it’s a great start. I’d encourage you to aim for 14 or fewer eventually, but this is a fantastic first step. How do you feel about checking in on this during your next appointment?
Yeah, that sounds good. I’ll give it a try.
That’s all we can ask for. I’m really glad you’re open to making these changes, Steve. Let’s see how it goes next month.
Hi there. Thanks for coming in today. What’s been on your mind lately?

Honestly, I’ve been struggling with my criminal history. It’s like no matter how hard I try to move forward, it feels like this shadow is always there, blocking me from becoming who I really want to be.
That sounds really heavy. It’s like you’re carrying this weight that keeps pulling you back, even though you’re trying so hard to move forward. What’s been the hardest part about it for you?
